The present position with regard to all axles other than the ones we have lowered to 5 per cent. and free is that they remain at 35 per cent. and 30 per cent. That is the duty that will remain operative. If the honorable senator wishes to make rollerbearing and ball-bearing axles, n.e.i., dutiable at 15 per cent. and 10 per cent., I am sorry to say that I cannot go that far. I hope the Committee will adhere to the present position.

speech.para: Senator Colonel NEILD. (New South Wales) [9.50]. - There seems to be some misapprehension on the part of the Minister of Home Affairs. Unfortunately, he did not Catch what I said on the subject. I must say that I desired to move the request in a general way, as is shown by the following paragraph from the letter I referred to -

quote.para: The reduction in draught of vehicles and waggons with Timken roller-bearing axles attached is from 40 per cent. to 80 per cent., according to the conditions ; and for heavy drawing, especially in the country, they will become indispensable.

speech.para: Having read that paragraph clearly, I was of the opinion that the Minister understood the position, and that I would have the opportunity later on of moving what I then mentioned - a request for the old rate of duty of 15 per cent. That the Committee assented to the importation of roller-bearing axles for motor car purposes at 5 per cent. and free shows that there was some reason for their introduction for that purpose. If they are of advantage for motor cars, surely they are of advantage to the general waggon users of the country, and as the Committee placed a duty of 35 per cent. on axles generally, I desired to have a duty of 15 per cent. on these particular axles. While the Minister objects to a duty of 15 per cent., I hope he understands that these articles are not made here.

talk.start.para: - Roller-bearing axles are being made here.

- It cannot he said that I made a mistake. The Minister objects to the duty being 15 per cent., and therefore I know I cannot carrymy request. If I am permitted, I will amend my request to make the general duty 25 per cent.

speech.para: Request amended accordingly, and negatived.
Division XV. - Musical Instruments -
Item 381. Musical Instruments n.e.i. ; Musical Boxes; Pianolas, and other Attachments or Articles for rendering Music by Mechanical Process; and Metronomes and the like, ad val. 20 per cent.

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to amend item 381 by leaving out the words " Musical Instruments n.e.i.," and adding the following new paragraph : - " (b) Musical Instruments n.e.i., 15 per cent."

speech.para: My reason for moving this request is that I recognise that the musical instruments mentioned in the item might be considered as belonging to what might be termed the luxuries of musical life, but other musical instruments come under an entirely different category.

talk.start.para: - Has my honorable friend overlooked item386, which permits military band instruments and other orchestral instruments to come in free ?
- Yes. I will withdraw the request.

speech.para: Request, by leave, withdrawn.
Item agreed to.
Item 382 (Organs, pipe);. and item 383 (Metal pipes for pipe organs) agreed to.
Item 384. Pianos, viz. : -

item.para: . . and on and after 12th December, 1907.

item.label: (a)
item.para: Grand and Semi-grand, ad val. (Gene- ral Tariff), 30 per cent. '; (United Kingdom), 25 per cent. . . .

talk.start.para: - - I intend to move a. request to the House of Representatives to make the duty on imports under the General Tariff 20 per cent. Much as I value time at present, seeing that we are all anxious in the interests of the Commonwealth to dispose of the Tariff, I recognise that this item should be carefully considered in all its details before allowing an increase 'of duty upon the old rate to take place. Therefore, I shall have to ask the indulgence of the Committee for giving reasons why the old rate of duty on pianos should be adhered to. There are two aspects from which this item can be debated. The first is. to view it from a purely business aspect, as has been 'done with regard to the manufacture of other goods such as starch, woollens, boots, and furniture. Then I would call the attention of the Committee to the higher stand-points from which a matter of this kind must be viewed. From the protectionist' stand-point, we have first to consider the terms and conditions under which' this industry was established, and is carried on. I am pleased to say that in New South Wales it has been conducted in a manner which has been highly creditable to its initiators. Not only was it started there under a freetrade Tariff, but it was developed to a very large extent indeed under that policy. It has been stated, I believe, that up to the introduction of the first Federal Tariff, when a general duty was imposed, Mr. Beale had been producing600 pianos per annum. When his manager was giving evidence before the Tariff Commission he did not ask for the imposition of an additional duty. He admitted that the out-' put from the factory had been increasing year by year since 1900. Other evidence in the same direction was given. It is quite evident that when he began to operate, Mr. Beale believed that in Australia there was an opening for a pianoforte industry under conditions that were very dissimilar from those which exist to-day. He must have held the opinion that the industry could be carried on without the aid of a duty, because he could not know that Federation would become an accomplished fact, or that New South Wales would have any other fiscal policy. Seeing that the industry progressed under free-trade conditions, we may assume that Mr. Beale thought that no duty was required to make it a success from the ordinary business stand-point. Under the Federation a duty of 20 per cent. was levied on pianofortes, and that also gave satisfaction to Mr. Beale. Not one iota of evidence has been adduced to show that from a business aspect he needs an additional duty as a manufacturer. From the report of the protectionist section of the Tariff Commission, I findthat Mr. Beale's manager claimed that his instruments were equal, if not superior, to any instruments made in any other part of the world. He did not ask for an increased duty, but stated that it would be to the interests of the Commonwealth if a higher duty were imposed on pianos in order to induce foreign manufacturers to start factories here. Both Mr. Beale and his representative admitted that every development which they could possibly desire was taking place in the business. The protectionist section of the Tariff Commission based their report on very shallow grounds, and 'with practically no evidence to support their recommendation. Mr. Marland, of Maryborough, in Queensland, told the Tariff Commission that he employed no hands, and desired a duty of 30 per cent. I find that equally poor evidence was given on the other side, because there was practically only one witness examined, and I do not suppose that the evidence is very reliable. I wish to deal with the cost of the imported and Australian pianos. It is a business axiom that the greater the output the larger the reduction in manufacturing expenses. Every manufacturer knows that, regardless of the output up to a certain point, his business lias to bear such charges as rent, taxes, salaries, interest, depreciation, and management. Of course, I do not include the cost of en- larging works or effecting alterations and repairs. May I be permitted, sir, to submit my request in a form different from that which I indicated at the beginning of my remarks?
- As the request has not yet been stated from the chair, it can be moved in any form that the honorable senator wishes.
- Then I move-

quote.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the duty on item 384, paragraph a, ad val. (imports under General Tariff), 25 per cent.

speech.para: It will be remembered by the Vice-President of the Executive Council that in another place the present duties of 30 and 25 per cent. were only carried by one vote. The duties which I am proposing represent a compromise, and are not in accord with my personal desire. If the honorable senator is prepared to accept the compromise I shall have no more to say.

talk.start.para: - Let us get to a division . and test the feeling of the Committee.
- Has the Minister agreed to this proposal?
- No.

- If the Minister would agree to what I suggest, the whole position would be altered. Honorable senators realize that the manufactured cost of any article is decreased according to the increase in the output.. We are, therefore, justified in assuming that, as Mr. Beale's annual output of pianos was 600 under free-trade, 1,500 under a duty of 20 per cent., and. is now between 1,700 and 1,800, the present manufacturing cost of his pianos must be very considerably less than it was when' he turned out only 600 under free-trade.
- And is not his price less also?

- I am arguing that the manufacturing cost must be less, and I think' the facts in connexion with the industry will show that Mr. Beale is able to manufacture as cheaply as are manufacturers elsewhere. If he was doing well, and his business was developing under free-trade with an output of only 600 each year, it is not unreasonable to assume that he is now doing an extraordinarily good business when he is selling three times the number of pianos, and has, besides, the advantage of this very high duty. It has been stated that Mr. Wertheim, a very large importer of pianos, intends to manu facture these instruments in Australia. He has stated that he would be perfectly satisfied to commence the manufacture of pianos in the Commonwealth under a duty of 25 per cent. When, in addition to that statement, it is known that Mr. Beale, on his own evidence, does not require any increased duty, I should like to be told what practical reason can be given for the increased duty proposed in this Tariff. When a local manufacturer is doing so well, making such large profits, and developing his business to such an extent as has been stated, and is satisfied with a duty of 25 per cent., and when Mr. Wertheim is prepared to start the manufacture of pianos in Australia under that duty, why should we tax the purchasers of pianos in Australia to the tune of 5 per cent. more to encourage an industry that is already thriving and progressing? To show that I am not overstating the case, I remind honorable senators that Mr. Beale, in the Adelaide Advertiser of 13th June, 1903, advertised -

quote.para: We sell Soo pianos a year in Australia.

speech.para: It will be found that Mr. Carl Johann Vader, manager for Beale and Company, gave the following evidence before the Tariff Commission. I refer honorable senators to question 96389 -

quote.para: How many pianos are you turning out? - Last year we turned out 1,500.
Is that your largest output? - We are now increasing it.
Has it been increasing every year since 1900 ? - Yes.

speech.para: At the present time, owing to the increased output, the cost price of Beale pianos must be less then in the years prior to 1903. With reference to the cost price prior to 1903, Mr. Beale writes, in a letter signed by himself, and dated 28th August, 1905-

quote.para: It is impossible to obtain by purchase pianos of the quality of our issue at even one-third more money (i.e., than the cost of his pianos) under free-trade.

speech.para: In another letter, signed by Mr. Beale himself, and dated 14th May, 1898, he wrote -

quote.para: The cost of German pianos comparable in quality(i.e., with his own) is 50 per cent. higher without duty.

speech.para: From that it would appear that Mr. Beale did not require the assistance of any duty at all. In 1897 and 1898 Mr. Beale supplied the following figures showing the cost price at his. factory of 439 pianos, and they show that the average factory cost per piano was£19 12s. 6d. -
Mr. Beale's output has been almost quadrupled since that time, and hence his present manufacturing cost must be very much lower than these figures denote. In his latest catalogue, Mr. Beale states -

quote.para: Our pianos are priced much lower than the better class of German pianos are priced in Europe itself.

speech.para: In June, 1902, Mr. Beale invoiced some pianos to a Melbourne firm, and I propose to quote from an exact copy of the invoice.

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator is fighting a very forlorn hope.

-I remind the honorable senator that I am not responsible for that. Lord Palmerston, a celebrated British statesman, when asked by a clergyman how he could enjoy himself when he realized the responsibilities of the position he held as Prime Minister of Great Britain, replied,

speech.para: I take every means in my power to faithfully consider every question brought before me, and I am not responsible for the consequences." I can assure Senator Needham that whether any speech I make influences a vote or not does not affect my sleep. The only thing that troubles me is that I may not do justice to the interests involved in this question, not only of the manufacturers and importers, but of the purchasers of pianos throughout Australia. The following is a copy of the invoice referred to - 484 George-street,
Sydney, 20th June, 1902.

Shipped per s.s. Warrego - 8 cases Beale Pianos as follows : - 2 Beale-Vader patent, Walnut, No. 1 Upright Grand, Nos. 13311, 13313, £28 10s.- £57, 2 Beale-Vader patent, Walnut, No. 2 Upright Grand,Nos. 13309, 13312,£31 10s. - £63. 2 Beale-Vader Patent, Walnut, No. 3 Upright Grand, Nos. 13288, 13281, £33. - £66. 2 Beale-Vader Patent, Walnut, No. 4 Boudoir Grand, Nos. 13271, 13285, £38-£76.

All with patented iron and. steel tuning-system, patented hitchpins, patented hexagonal strings in bass, Isermann action, iron action standards, nickled gun-metal brackets and pressure-bars. Double-sconces.

It should be noted that these invoice prices include the following': - Manufacturing cost, case and cost of packing, all freight and other expenses of shipment to Melbourne, and Mr. Beale's factory profit. His cost prices therefore must be very much less than the figures referred to in the invoice. From corrected and departmental figures furnished by the Customs authorities, I find that in 1906, 12,263 pianos were imported at an average cost of £22 10s., which is higher than the factory cost of Beale's pianos in 1897 and 1898, notwithstanding his then limited output. The imparted pianos included a number of very cheap instruments imported by furniture shops, which tended to lower the average price of pianos in good repute imported from first-class makers. The statement has been made by Beale and Company that the cost of importing is very much less than some of the importers make out, inasmuch as freights have been as low as 5s. per ton. We know that a few years ago, owing to a freight war which sometimes exists among shipping companies, very low freights were in vogue. But I am in a position to give honorable senators information as to the average freight ruling during the last three or four years. I received the following letter from James Service and Company -

quote.para: Dear Sir, - Freight on pianos. - Referring to your verbal inquiries as to the rates of freight ruling from Germany by steamer for the past 3 years, namely 1905-6-7, we beg to inform you that a reference to the company's Hand Book shows that freight per German-Australian S.S. Company's, steamers from German ports to Melbourne during the period named was32s. per cubic metre of 35.3 cubic feet. Trusting that this information will be useful to you,
We are,

speech.para: Jas. Service & Co.
I have the followingfrom the NorddeutscherLloyd Company -

quote.para: With reference to your inquiry, we beg to inform you that the ruling freight on pianos per our steamers from Hamburg during the past three years has been about 40s. per ton of 40 cubic feet.

speech.para: I may mention that the highest class of imported pianos, such as Lipp, Bechstein; Steinway, Ronisch, Schwechten, Bluthner, Broadwood, and Erard, cost more than double the price of Beale's pianos to import. To the invoice price of these highclass imported pianos must be added very heavy expenses of importation of such bulky articles. The average expenses incurred in the importation of an upright piano invoiced at £20 from the factory abroad to the warehouse in Melbourne is as follows -

quote.para: Case and packing, £2 5s. ; expenses from factory, f .o.b. Hamburg, 15s. ; sea freight, 32 cubic feet, £3 5s. ; wharfage at Melbourne, 5s. per 40 feet; stocking at Melbourne, is. 8d. per 40 feet ; cartage to Melbourne, 3s. ; unpacking and polishing, 7s. ; insurance at 12s. 6d. per cent, on £20, 2s. 6d. ; buying commission, 2^ per cent, on j£20, ios. ; interest and exchange, 3^ per cent, on £20, 14s. ; total, ,£8 us. od. On a piano invoiced at £3$ the charges would be about 19s. additional or £9 ios. 9d. in all. . These figures represent the fair average cost of importing direct from Germany; vid London the charges would, of course, be higher. During a recent freight war ocean freights were temporarily lower, but the charge has now gone back to the old figure.
At that time there was a war of freights between' sailing vessels, and very lowfreights were taken; but that is one of the exceptions that prove the rule-

From these facts it is abundantly evident that Mr. Beale's written statement that he manufactures pianos at lower prices than they can be imported into Australia is correct. It is also evident that there is no ground fo'r any increase in the duty. Mr. Beale knows this well, for in a letter written and signed by himself in February, 1902, referring to his piano manufacturing business, Mr. Beale states - " Now the whole concern is in a very complete and strong position, irrespective of Tariffs."-
Without any duty he himself acknowledged that his firm was not only manufacturing pianos, but was healthy and progressive -

Mr. Beale in his advertisements shows that he has another advantage over the British and foreign manufacturers. He openly states - " No patent for any parts, of pianos have been taken out in Australia from abroad. Hence the entire field of discovery and practice is open to us which is not open to any manufacturer in the world." This means that other manufacturers have to respect patent rights and pay royalties for using the results of inventors' brains. Mr. Beale simply appropriates these without payment - and boasts of it.

Although this statement has been handed to me, personally I do not complain so much as some of our importing friends do, because I recognise that Mr. Beale as a manufacturer, so long as he acts fairly from a business point of view, is within his rights ; but it is unfair that he should take an advantage in that way, and boast of it.

talk.start.para: - Why not have a division and test the feeling of the Committee ?

- As the honorable senator has announced that he has made up his mind, I am trying to bring sufficient facts to bear upon him to induce him to treat this matter in the interests of Australia. -Senator Needham. - I never stated that I had made up my mind.

- I am treating the subject at present from a purely . business aspect, although I regard it from a very much higher stand-point. The present duty is almost prohibitive on the ordinary pianos . which the middle and working classes can buy. There is scarcely a home in Australia in which, if the man is of sav-ing habits, there will not be found two articles which are both absolute necessaries in their respective ways - a sewing machine and a piano. The use of the piano should be encouraged in every possible way in order to promote the .cultivation of the great gift of harmony which the Almighty has given to us -

speech.para: The average expenses connected with the importation of a piano invoiced at '^20 are, as previously shown, £8 11s. gd. per instrument. On a piano invoiced at ^35 they amount to £9 ios. gd. per instrument. That is a- natural protection, of 42 per cent, on a piano invoiced at £20, and of 30 per cent, on a piano invoiced at ^35.
The present duties were only carried by one vote in another place -

Only about one-tenth of the pianos imported are of British manufacture (see Customs Returns for 1906) as a considerable number of German pianos come vid England. Hence the duty will on nine-tenths of the imports be 30 per cent. In assessing the value for duty one-tenth is added to the invoice, price under the Customs Act, making the duty 33 per cent., and the duty is also collected on all expenses to f.o.b. at port of shipment at the same rate. This will make the duty over 35 per cent, on prime cost. Add the natural protection to the duty of 33 per cent., and Mr. Beale will have a total protection on pianos invoiced at ,£20 of about 77 per cent., and' on those invoiced at ,£35 a protection of about 65 per cent. It is safe to say that very few manufacturers receive or expect to receive such a prohibitive protection as the proposed Tariff offers to Mr. Beale.

As for the pianoforte industry languishing, it is admitted by all manufacturers, present and prospective, that it was in a most flourishing condition under free-trade conditions and under a 20 per cent, duty, and is so under the present rates. That is proved by the profits Mr. Beale was making- under free-trade, when he was satisfied with that condition of affairs. Those profits must be very much greater now, taking into consideration the large additional output and the necessarily decreased expenses. When a manufacturer is satisfied with things as they are, and a prospective manufacturer asks for nothing more than 25 per cent., the Committee, in the interests of the public at large, should realize that any increase of duty will simply be a tax upon all those who use pianos over and above those manufactured here -

quote.para: Under Federation he obtained free access to the markets of all the other States, from which he had previously been excluded by heavy duties. Aduty of 20 per cent. was imposed on all imported pianosby the first Federal Tariff, and Mr. Beale was thus put in a very strong position. As before shown, his output has increased from 439 pianos in the year 1897-8 to over 1,500 in the year 1905, and is still increasing. These facts demonstrate that the business is not languishing for want of a higher duty, and the duty of 30 per cent. and 25 per cent. makes the position of Beale as the holder of a monopoly sounder than ever. Mr. Beale, in a letter written and signed by himself-

talk.start.para: - Let us get to a division.

- I have only just begum. This is to me one of the most serious questions in the whole Tariff. I should not have taken 'the responsibility of occupying the time of the Committee if I had not felt that this was a tax upon the cultivation of one of the greatest gifts given to mankind.
- Upon one of the necessaries of life?

- It is a necessary of life in a certain sense, and the honorable senator, if he desired the best musical education for his daughters, would see the advantages of obtaining the best instruments he could get. To many of us music is one of the pleasures of life, and we hope to allow others to enjoy the same pleasure.
- Cannot the Australian make a piano to provide harmony in his own home?

- The honorable senator told me on one occasion that fish is fish ; so a piano is a piano, and a fiddle is a fiddle ; but would the honorable senator know the difference between a common violin costing 15s. and a Stradivarius worth£700? Australians can make pianos, and I am glad of it, but common sense rebels against 'the assertion that he can make them equal to those turned out by the finest experts in other countries, with all the benefits of generations of artistic skill. Does Senator Needham mean to tell me that those instruments with which the Besses o' the Barn band charmed thousands of people in Australia
- All those instruments are admitted free.
- Why? Does the honorable senator say that musical instruments cannot be made in Australia?
- The particular musical instruments now before the Committee can be made in Australia.

- Cannot we make musical instruments for brass and other bands? Senator Trenwith would say that if they are' not made here they ought to be, and so a duty ought to be imposed on them. Much of the charm of the music of that famous band came from the highly-trained skill of the English workmen composing the band, but much of it came also from the quality of the instruments themselves. . Musical instruments of that kind can be made in Australia, but no leading band would think of using an Australian-made instrument unless its quality had been proved to the satisfaction, not of politicians, but of the best musicians in the world. The conditions which make it necessary that those instruments should be admitted free absolutely rule with regard to pianos.
- I thought you were in a hurry to get the Tariff through ?
- If the honorable senator had been in as great a hurry to get the Tariff through as I have been he would have spared giving the Senate fifty speeches during the Tariff, whilst I have only made two.
- What a. statement!

- If the honorable senator looks at Hansard I venture to say that he will find that I have not made two speeches of more than ten minutes each on the Tariff, whilst Senator Lynch will be found to have made fifty. Mr. Beale has an absolute monopoly in the manufacture of pianos so far as Australia is concerned. I do not say that he is misusing that monopoly, nor do I enter into the personal side of the question at all, except to say that I consider it only fair to the importers to point out instances where I think Mr. Beale has unfairly attacked them. Whilst I have given some facts which I have discovered for myself and others which have been given me by importers interested in the matter, I may state that I do not put forward theopinions furnished me as absolutely being my view of the question, because if I wereto take the importers' view I might be a little biased in their direction, and if I took Mr. Beale's view I might be a little biased in his direction. Therefore I ask the Committee to take the evidence and test it from a practical stand-point. Mr. Beale poses as a very strong protectionist. Yet we find that. the advertisements of his pianos on the railway stations are imported, whereas he could get them printed here. I am not blaming Mr. Beale personally.
- I am, though.

- If I were a manufacturer and could get my printing at a rate of 50 per cent. less from abroad, I think it would be a fair business deal. I would do absolutely the same as Mr. Beale. Whilst paying the duties that the Commonwealth consider fair and equitable if the prices of the local articles were above those of the imported articles, I consider that I would have a perfect right to go to the Old Country or anywhere else for my goods. At the same time it does seem odd that a gentleman who poses as a strong protecttionist, and who is looked upon almost as a prohibitionist, should patronize foreign countries for the goods he wants instead of the country in which he monopolizes a certain industry.
- Mr. Beale could have and should have got his enamel printing done in Australia.

- He should not pose as such an extreme protectionist. To show I was correct in my statement as to Mr. Wertheim, I would point out that he has stated that he is prepared to establish a factory in Melbourne for the manufacture of pianos provided that the rate of duty is fixed at 25 per cent. Since making that statement Mr. Wertheim has notified the public through the columns of the Herald that he has purchased ground, and is about to establish a factory. If Mr. Wertheim with a 25 per cent. duty is prepared to come into competition with Mr. Beale, the only manufacturer of pianos in Australia, a man whose industry has -been established for ten years, who has a large factory with plant and machinery well laid down, and who advertises that he manufactures 1,600 pianos yearly, that should be a guarantee that a 25 per cent, duty is the maximum manufacturers of pianos in Australia wish for. In my opinion 25 per cent. is too much.I have a circular which has been issued by a very large number of importers, but I confess that it is very much on the same lines as the position which I have endeavoured to place before the Committee, and therefore I do not think it necessary to read it. Mr. Beale made some very unfair charges against the importers, but I will only take a few items in respect to which . complaint has been made. Mr. Beale made a statement with regard to certain pianos being sold retail at very large profits as against their cost to the importers. In connexion with that matter Mr. Beale's circular states -

quote.para: Messrs. Allan and Company say - " Our cheapest is Thiirmer, about £20 10s., including case." A partner in Messrs. Chappell & Co., of London and Liverpool, travelling recently through Australia, asked permission to visit our factories. " The importers abused you so violently in Melbourne and Sydney that I wished particularly to see for myself." He came, inspected everything, and expressed much satisfaction, remarking, " I am delighted to see that a British concern here in Australia makes such headway against these Germans. I was disgusted to find that Thiirmer pianos, exactly as sold to us delivered in Liverpool, freight paid and cases included, at £20 are sold in Australia by dealers at£75 retail." Thiirmer is a fifth-rate shop at Meissen, a small town of Saxony.

speech.para: That is a distinct statement made to honorable senators. That statement was made by Messrs. Beale and Company, and I think that I am perfectly justified in giving the reply of the other side. Mr . Beale, quite unnecessarily, taunts the importers with having resorted practically to corruption, because they have sought to put their views before honorable senators.

talk.start.para: - He should be brought to the bar of the Senate.

- I do not think that in this respect the one side is better than the other. Mr. Beale has. done his fair share of lobbying ; he has done his best to influence honorable members of both Houses, and if he was justified in doing so the importers were equally justified in resorting to the same practice. For my own part, I do not think that lobbying should be indulged in by any one.
- What does the honorable senator think of the Beale piano ?

- I am glad that Mr. Beale has succeeded in establishing a piano manufactory in New South Wales: I am personally acquainted with him, and wish him prosperity, just as I wish success to all our manufacturers. I should be sorry to cast any' reflection on Mr. Beale or his pianos, although I think that in some repects he has acted indiscreetly and has jumped at conclusions that are scarcely fair. In a circular which I shall be pleased to show any honorable senator, the importers prove conclusively that with one exception the maximum price charged by them for a Thiirmer piano has been £.50. In one case a charge of £56 was made; but that was because of some special features .that it possessed. Having regard to the freight, advertising, and other charges, as well as the fact that these instruments are sold in many cases on the deferred payment system; ^50 is, I venture to say, a reasonable price, and about equal to that which Mr. Beale would charge for a piano of his own manufacture. My experience is that, taking value for value, the imported piano is equal to any that Mr. Beale can manufacture. In this circular, we have the statement that -

quote.para: Mr. Beale quoted an assertion that "Thur" mer pianos, exactly as delivered in Liverpool, freight paid and cases included, at £20, are sold in Australia by dealers at £75. This statement Mr. Beale unblushingly repeats, although he knows of .our contradiction, dated the 6th December, 1907, in which we showed that the average selling price of the "Thurmer pianos was under £50, and that we had never sold a "Thurmer" piano at anything like so high a price as £75.

speech.para: I feel very strongly upon this question. The gift of music is one of the greatest with which man is endowed, and adds materially to his social' enjoyment. The Australians are a musical people. - Our climate has perhaps something to do with our leanings in that direction, whilst the love of music so common amongst the people of- the Commonwealth may be accentuated by the fact that owing to our sparse population we have not the opportunity for enjoyment in other directions which more thickly-populated countries offer. There are few homes in Australia in which there is- not a piano.- Every parent is ready 10 incur considerable expenditure in giving his children a musical education. In Victoria alone 2,500 music teachers signed a petition praying the Parliament not to increase the duty on pianos under the first Fe'deral Tariff. A similar petition was signed by 700 teachers in New South Wales. Had the pianoforte teachers, throughout Australia been appealed to, I am sure that at least 10,000 would have petitioned Parliament not to increase the old rates of duty.

talk.start.para: - Do not l.er us miss our trains.

- I understand that Senator Vardon also desires to speak to the question, and I think therefore that the Minister should either agree that progress be reported at' once, or accept the compromise I have suggested. .1 have produced conclusive evidence that there is . no necessity for this increased duty. ' Nevertheless, I am prepared to agree to the old rate being increased by 5 per cent., and I hope that that- compromise will be accepted. Surely music teachers should be capable of expressing an opinion upon this question. The Vice-President of the Executive Council would consider it little short of impertinence for a layman to express an opinion upon a question of law, and surely he should be ready to concede that those who devote their time and attention to the teaching of music are competent to express an opinion upon this question. There is not a great singer, or young pianist of promise, who. does not leave Australia for Berlin, Leipsic, or some other place to- finish his musical education .for the simple reason that in this respect Germany sets a standard.
- There is no comparison between the teacher and the piano !

- There is, inasmuch as the music teacher tries to bring to fruition the gifts which have been given the children; and to that end the best instruments possible must be obtained. No musician is satisfied with any but the best, which should be freely admitted as a means of education to all concerned in the advance of music. Of course, other conditions being equal, preference' "will be given to the local article, but, for all the reasons I have suggested, I think the compromise offered ought to be accepted.

. - I am surprised at the attempt toincrease the duties on pianos. Under theTariff of 1902 a duty of 20 per cent, wassufficient to enable this industry to prosper.. I have no desire to depreciate the colonial made instrument, which I have every reason to believe is good in- all respects; but when a manufacturer is able, under the duty I have mentioned, to expand his business andflourish, it is somewhat indecent to suggest a higher impost. I regard a tax on pianos, as a tax on the home. We ought to do all we can to cultivate the art of music, thar* which there is no more' refining influence, and I should like to see a piano in the home of every man, because it is very often the means of keeping the family together, and. out of mischief : A piano is good in every home.
- We all believe that.

- Then the honorable senator ought to vote for a duty of 20 per cent: if the duty proposed be imposed, an absolute monopoly will be givento' Mr. Beale, who is at present doing very- well. How long will it be before Mr. Beale, pr any other local manufacturer, will be able to supply the wants of the Commonwealth? In the meantime, the people are to be taxed to the extraordinary extent proposed.
- Other people have intimated their intention of starting factories.

- So much the better, but it will be many years before the local output will be equal to the demand. My advice is to allow the business to expand gradually as hitherto. We ought to do everything possible to cultivate music as a refining influence amongst our people. The facts which have been put before us show that a duty of20 per cent. would give adequate protection to the local manufacturer of pianos, and if that rate is moved for 1 shall support the request.

division.header.para: Question - That the House of Representatives be requested to make the duty on item 384, paragraph' a (Imports under General Tariff), ad val. 25 per cent. (Senator Gray's request) - put. The Committee divided.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the duty on item 384, paragraph a (imports from the United Kingdom), ad val. 20 per cent.

speech.para: It has been stated over and oyer again that most of the pianos which are now imported are of German manufacture, but that the English pianos are equally good, if not superior. In view of that fact, and of theconstant statement of Ministers that they desire to give preference to English manufacturers, I hope that my request will be agreed to.
Senator Colonel NEILD , (New South Wales) [11.22]. - Does the Minister consent to this?

talk.start.para: - No.

- Then, in allfriendliness, I ask him to report progress, because I should like to speak on the proposal before the Committee, and I have toomuch respect for honorable senators, some of whom have only just returned from travelling in the wilds, to keep the Committee sitting longer at this hour. No time will be lost if I am given an opportunity to speak to-morrow. If I speak now, I shall occupy perhaps half-an--hour, which I recognise it would not be fair to do at this time of night.
- Let me finish this division.
- No; that is unreasonable.
- We have got through five pages of the Tariff to-day.
- Then, if honorable senators allow me to take item 384, I shall consent to the reporting of progress.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.
